Cosmic Loom Theory
  • API Reference
  • View page source

API Reference

This section documents the Python API for Cosmic Loom Theory simulations.

Simulators

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_wave.LoomfieldSimulator

2D numerical solver for the Loomfield wave equation.

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_3d.LoomfieldSimulator3D

3D numerical solver for the Loomfield wave equation.

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_3d_realtime.LoomfieldSimulator3DRealtime

Optimized 3D Loomfield simulator for real-time rendering.

Visualizers

visualizations.interactive.energy_resistance.EnergyResistanceVisualizer

Interactive visualizer for the Energy Resistance phase space.

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_wave.LoomfieldVisualizer

Interactive animated visualization of Loomfield dynamics.

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_3d.LoomfieldVisualizer3D

Interactive 3D visualization of the Loomfield.

Core Classes

LoomfieldSimulator (2D)

class visualizations.interactive.loomfield_wave.LoomfieldSimulator(grid_size=200, domain_size=10.0, v_L=1.0, kappa_L=2.0, damping=0.001)[source]

Bases: object

2D numerical solver for the Loomfield wave equation.

Uses finite difference method with absorbing boundary conditions to simulate wave propagation and coherence dynamics.

Parameters:

  • grid_size (int)

  • domain_size (float)

  • v_L (float)

  • kappa_L (float)

  • damping (float)

__init__(grid_size=200, domain_size=10.0, v_L=1.0, kappa_L=2.0, damping=0.001)[source]

Initialize the Loomfield simulator.

Parameters:

  • grid_size (int) – Number of grid points per dimension

  • domain_size (float) – Physical size of the domain

  • v_L (float) – Loomfield propagation speed

  • kappa_L (float) – Coupling constant for coherence density

  • damping (float) – Dissipation rate (biological energy loss)

add_source(x, y, strength=1.0, radius=0.3, frequency=2.0, phase=0.0, source_type='oscillating')[source]

Add a coherence source at position (x, y).

Parameters:

  • x (float) – Position in domain coordinates

  • y (float) – Position in domain coordinates

  • strength (float) – Source amplitude

  • radius (float) – Spatial extent of source

  • frequency (float) – Oscillation frequency (for oscillating sources)

  • phase (float) – Initial phase offset (for phase-locking multiple sources)

  • source_type (str) – ‘oscillating’, ‘pulse’, or ‘static’

clear_sources()[source]

Remove all coherence sources.

add_perturbation(x, y, strength=2.0, radius=1.0)[source]

Add a perturbation (disruption) to the field.

Perturbations inject HIGH-FREQUENCY chaotic noise that disrupts spatial coherence. This fragments phase relationships, lowering Q even though total energy may increase.

Key insight: Coherence requires smooth, organized structure. Perturbations destroy this by adding sharp, uncorrelated variations.

Parameters:

  • x (float)

  • y (float)

  • strength (float)

  • radius (float)

step(n_steps=1)[source]

Advance the simulation by n_steps timesteps.

Implements the driven wave equation: ∂²L/∂t² = v_L² * ∇²L - damping * ∂L/∂t

Sources inject energy directly into the field velocity, creating outward-propagating waves. This is physically equivalent to oscillating membranes or antennas driving the Loomfield.

Parameters:

n_steps (int)

get_total_coherence()[source]

Calculate Q: TRUE spatial coherence (ENERGY-INDEPENDENT).

Coherence measures how ORGANIZED the field is - how well different regions maintain consistent phase relationships. This is computed as:

  1. Spatial autocorrelation: How correlated is the field at different distances?

  2. Roughness penalty: High-frequency noise = low coherence

CRITICAL: Q is NORMALIZED by energy, so: - High energy + chaos = LOW Q - Low energy + organization = HIGH Q - Perturbations add noise → Q DROPS

Q range: [0, ~2] where 1.0 = baseline organized field

Return type:

float

get_consciousness_metric()[source]

Calculate C_bio from CLT v1.1 Section 7.6: C_bio = ∫ ρ_coh · Λ dV

Where Λ (Section 7.2) captures “rate of Loomfield reconfiguration”.

KEY CLT INSIGHT (Section 7.6): “High local activity without integration does not yield robust conscious experience, nor does static coherence without active dynamics.”

This means C_bio requires BOTH: 1. COHERENCE (Q): Field must be organized, not chaotic 2. DYNAMICS (|∂L/∂t|): Field must be actively changing, not static

Implementation: C_bio = Q × ∫|ρ_coh|·|∂L/∂t| dV

C_bio is HIGH when: Coherent, organized field is actively oscillating C_bio is LOW when: - Field is CHAOTIC (Q low) even if active → no integration - Field is STATIC (∂L/∂t ≈ 0) even if coherent → no dynamics - No sources (ρ_coh ≈ 0) → nothing to integrate

Return type:

float

get_field_energy()[source]

Get total field energy (for comparison with coherence).

Return type:

float

reset()[source]

Reset simulation to initial state.

LoomfieldSimulator3D

class visualizations.interactive.loomfield_3d.LoomfieldSimulator3D(grid_size=64, domain_size=10.0, v_L=1.0, kappa_L=2.0, damping=0.002)[source]

Bases: object

3D numerical solver for the Loomfield wave equation.

Uses finite difference method with absorbing boundary conditions on all 6 faces to simulate wave propagation in 3D space.

The Loomfield L(r,t) is a continuous field - not particles or objects. This simulator captures coherence dynamics in biological volumes.

Parameters:

  • grid_size (int)

  • domain_size (float)

  • v_L (float)

  • kappa_L (float)

  • damping (float)

__init__(grid_size=64, domain_size=10.0, v_L=1.0, kappa_L=2.0, damping=0.002)[source]

Initialize the 3D Loomfield simulator.

Parameters:

  • grid_size (int) – Number of grid points per dimension (N×N×N)

  • domain_size (float) – Physical size of the cubic domain

  • v_L (float) – Loomfield propagation speed

  • kappa_L (float) – Coupling constant for coherence density

  • damping (float) – Dissipation rate (slightly higher in 3D for stability)

add_source(x, y, z, strength=1.0, radius=0.5, frequency=1.5, phase=0.0, source_type='oscillating')[source]

Add a coherence source at position (x, y, z).

In 3D, sources generate spherical waves that propagate outward. Phase-locked sources create organized interference patterns.

Parameters:

  • x (float)

  • y (float)

  • z (float)

  • strength (float)

  • radius (float)

  • frequency (float)

  • phase (float)

  • source_type (str)

clear_sources()[source]

Remove all coherence sources.

add_perturbation(x, y, z, strength=2.0, radius=1.5)[source]

Add a spherical perturbation (disruption) to the field.

Injects high-frequency noise that fragments spatial coherence. Uses minimal smoothing to preserve high-frequency content that disrupts organized wave patterns.

Parameters:

  • x (float)

  • y (float)

  • z (float)

  • strength (float)

  • radius (float)

step(n_steps=1)[source]

Advance the simulation by n_steps timesteps.

Implements the 3D wave equation with absorbing boundaries.

Parameters:

n_steps (int)

get_total_coherence()[source]

Calculate Q: spatial coherence metric (3D version).

Measures how organized/coordinated the field is across the volume.

Return type:

float

get_consciousness_metric()[source]

Calculate C_bio: consciousness observable (3D version).

C_bio = Q³ × ∫|ρ_coh|·|∂L/∂t| dV

Uses Q³ (stronger than 2D’s Q²) because 3D chaotic dynamics accumulate more activity volume. The cubic penalty ensures consciousness requires strong coherence, not just activity.

Return type:

float

get_field_energy()[source]

Get total field energy.

Return type:

float

reset()[source]

Reset simulation to initial state.

get_slice(axis='z', position=0.0)[source]

Extract a 2D slice through the 3D field.

Parameters:

  • axis (str) – ‘x’, ‘y’, or ‘z’ - normal to the slice plane

  • position (float) – Position along the axis (-domain/2 to +domain/2)

Returns:

(slice_data, coord1, coord2) for plotting

Return type:

Tuple[ndarray, ndarray, ndarray]

get_isosurface_data(threshold=0.5)[source]

Get data for isosurface rendering at given threshold.

Returns positive and negative surfaces separately for proper coloring (gold vs blue in CLT visualization).

Parameters:

threshold (float)

Return type:

Tuple[ndarray, ndarray]

EnergyResistanceVisualizer

class visualizations.interactive.energy_resistance.EnergyResistanceVisualizer(ep_range=(0.1, 10.0), freq_range=(0.1, 5.0), resolution=500)[source]

Bases: object

Interactive visualizer for the Energy Resistance phase space.

Displays the relationship between Energy Present (EP), frequency (f), and Energy Resistance (éR), highlighting the viable window for biological coherence.

Parameters:

  • ep_range (Tuple[float, float])

  • freq_range (Tuple[float, float])

  • resolution (int)

DEFAULT_ER_MIN = 0.5
DEFAULT_ER_MAX = 5.0
COLORMAP_COLORS = [(0.4, 0.0, 0.6), (0.6, 0.2, 0.8), (0.2, 0.8, 0.4), (0.0, 0.6, 0.8), (0.0, 0.2, 0.6)]
__init__(ep_range=(0.1, 10.0), freq_range=(0.1, 5.0), resolution=500)[source]

Initialize the visualizer.

Parameters:

  • ep_range (Tuple[float, float]) – (min, max) range for Energy Present axis

  • freq_range (Tuple[float, float]) – (min, max) range for frequency axis

  • resolution (int) – Grid resolution for the phase space

trajectories: List[dict]
static calculate_er(ep, freq)[source]

Calculate Energy Resistance: éR = EP / f²

Parameters:

  • ep (ndarray) – Energy Present values

  • freq (ndarray) – Frequency values

Returns:

Energy Resistance values

Return type:

ndarray

add_trajectory(ep_values, freq_values, label='System', color='white', show_arrow=True)[source]

Add a system trajectory to the visualization.

Parameters:

  • ep_values (ndarray) – Array of EP values over time

  • freq_values (ndarray) – Array of frequency values over time

  • label (str) – Label for the trajectory

  • color (str) – Line color

  • show_arrow (bool) – Whether to show direction arrow

add_example_trajectories()[source]

Add example trajectories demonstrating different system behaviors.

setup_plot(figsize=(14, 10))[source]

Set up the matplotlib figure and axes.

Parameters:

figsize (Tuple[int, int])

render(interactive=True, show_trajectories=True, save_path=None)[source]

Render the complete visualization.

Parameters:

  • interactive (bool) – Whether to show interactive controls

  • show_trajectories (bool) – Whether to display example trajectories

  • save_path (str | None) – If provided, save figure to this path

create_static_figure(save_path=None)[source]

Create a static (non-interactive) version for publications.

Parameters:

save_path (str | None)

Utility Functions

Energy Resistance

visualizations.interactive.energy_resistance.calculate_system_er(energy_present, frequency)[source]

Calculate éR for a given system state and determine its regime.

Parameters:

  • energy_present (float) – Current energy in the system

  • frequency (float) – Fundamental frequency of the system

Returns:

Dictionary with éR value and regime classification

Return type:

dict

3D Visualization

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_3d.create_volumetric_figure(sim, render_mode='volume', opacity_scale=0.5)[source]

Create a plotly figure with volumetric rendering of the Loomfield.

Parameters:

  • sim (LoomfieldSimulator3D) – The 3D Loomfield simulator

  • render_mode (str) – ‘volume’ (continuous 3D volume) or ‘isosurface’ (nested shells)

  • opacity_scale (float) – Overall opacity multiplier (0.0-1.0)

The field is visualized with a gold colorscale where: - Brighter = higher field amplitude (more coherent) - Darker = lower field amplitude

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_3d.create_slice_figure(sim, axis='z', position=0.0)[source]

Create a 2D slice through the 3D Loomfield.

Useful for examining interior structure without full volumetric rendering.

Parameters:

  • sim (LoomfieldSimulator3D)

  • axis (str)

  • position (float)

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_3d.create_animated_figure(sim, n_frames=60, steps_per_frame=5, opacity_scale=0.6)[source]

Create an animated 3D figure showing wave propagation over time.

Parameters:

  • sim (LoomfieldSimulator3D) – Simulator with sources already configured

  • n_frames (int) – Number of animation frames

  • steps_per_frame (int) – Simulation steps between frames

  • opacity_scale (float) – Volume opacity

Returns:

Plotly figure with animation frames and play button

Preset Functions

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_3d.create_healthy_preset(sim)[source]

Healthy: Phase-locked sources creating coherent interference.

Central source + shell of synchronized satellites. Should produce high Q, high C_bio, calm visual appearance.

Parameters:

sim (LoomfieldSimulator3D)

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_3d.create_pathology_preset(sim)[source]

Pathology: Incoherent sources with different frequencies.

Scattered sources, no phase-locking, chaotic interference. Should produce low Q, low C_bio, noisy visual appearance.

Parameters:

sim (LoomfieldSimulator3D)

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_3d.create_healing_preset(sim)[source]

Healing: Re-coupling toward coherence.

Sources with same frequency but phase gradients, creating organized traveling waves that converge.

Parameters:

sim (LoomfieldSimulator3D)

Module Reference

visualizations.interactive

Interactive visualization tools for Cosmic Loom Theory.

Available visualizers: - EnergyResistanceVisualizer: éR = EP/f² phase space with viable window - LoomfieldVisualizer: Real-time 2D Loomfield wave propagation - LoomfieldVisualizer3D: 3D volumetric Loomfield visualization (plotly)

class visualizations.interactive.EnergyResistanceVisualizer(ep_range=(0.1, 10.0), freq_range=(0.1, 5.0), resolution=500)[source]

  • freq_range (Tuple[float, float])

  • resolution (int)

get_total_coherence()[source]

Calculate Q: TRUE spatial coherence (ENERGY-INDEPENDENT).

Coherence measures how ORGANIZED the field is - how well different regions maintain consistent phase relationships. This is computed as:

  1. Spatial autocorrelation: How correlated is the field at different distances?

CRITICAL: Q is NORMALIZED by energy, so: - High energy + chaos = LOW Q - Low energy + organization = HIGH Q - Perturbations add noise → Q DROPS

float

get_consciousness_metric()[source]

Calculate C_bio from CLT v1.1 Section 7.6: C_bio = ∫ ρ_coh · Λ dV

Where Λ (Section 7.2) captures “rate of Loomfield reconfiguration”.

KEY CLT INSIGHT (Section 7.6): “High local activity without integration does not yield robust conscious experience, nor does static coherence without active dynamics.”

This means C_bio requires BOTH: 1. COHERENCE (Q): Field must be organized, not chaotic 2. DYNAMICS (|∂L/∂t|): Field must be actively changing, not static

Implementation: C_bio = Q × ∫|ρ_coh|·|∂L/∂t| dV

Return type:

float

class visualizations.interactive.LoomfieldVisualizer(grid_size=200)[source]

Interactive animated visualization of Loomfield dynamics.

Features:

  • Real-time wave propagation animation

  • Color-coded coherence intensity

  • Click to add coherence sources

  • Parameter adjustment sliders

  • Preset scenarios (healthy, pathology, healing)

  • Perturbation mode

Parameters:

grid_size (int)

COLORMAP_COLORS = [(0.1, 0.2, 0.6), (0.2, 0.4, 0.8), (0.15, 0.25, 0.45), (0.05, 0.05, 0.1), (0.25, 0.2, 0.1), (0.7, 0.5, 0.2), (1.0, 0.85, 0.4), (1.0, 1.0, 0.9)]
__init__(grid_size=200)[source]

Initialize the visualizer with a simulator instance.

Parameters:

grid_size (int)

setup_plot(figsize=(16, 10))[source]

Set up the matplotlib figure with all UI elements.

Parameters:

figsize (Tuple[int, int])

run(interval=30, save_path=None)[source]

Run the interactive visualization.

Parameters:

  • interval (int) – Animation frame interval in milliseconds

  • save_path (str | None) – If provided, save a screenshot to this path

visualizations.interactive.loomfield_demo()

Run a demonstration of the Loomfield Wave visualizer.

class visualizations.interactive.LoomfieldSimulator3D(grid_size=64, domain_size=10.0, v_L=1.0, kappa_L=2.0, damping=0.002)[source]

3D numerical solver for the Loomfield wave equation.

Uses finite difference method with absorbing boundary conditions on all 6 faces to simulate wave propagation in 3D space.

The Loomfield L(r,t) is a continuous field - not particles or objects. This simulator captures coherence dynamics in biological volumes.

Parameters:

  • grid_size (int)

  • domain_size (float)

  • v_L (float)

  • kappa_L (float)

  • damping (float)

__init__(grid_size=64, domain_size=10.0, v_L=1.0, kappa_L=2.0, damping=0.002)[source]

Initialize the 3D Loomfield simulator.

Parameters:

  • grid_size (int) – Number of grid points per dimension (N×N×N)

  • domain_size (float) – Physical size of the cubic domain

  • v_L (float) – Loomfield propagation speed

  • kappa_L (float) – Coupling constant for coherence density

  • damping (float) – Dissipation rate (slightly higher in 3D for stability)

add_source(x, y, z, strength=1.0, radius=0.5, frequency=1.5, phase=0.0, source_type='oscillating')[source]

Add a coherence source at position (x, y, z).

In 3D, sources generate spherical waves that propagate outward. Phase-locked sources create organized interference patterns.

Parameters:

  • x (float)

  • y (float)

  • z (float)

  • strength (float)

  • radius (float)

  • frequency (float)

  • phase (float)

  • source_type (str)

clear_sources()[source]

Remove all coherence sources.

add_perturbation(x, y, z, strength=2.0, radius=1.5)[source]

Add a spherical perturbation (disruption) to the field.

Injects high-frequency noise that fragments spatial coherence. Uses minimal smoothing to preserve high-frequency content that disrupts organized wave patterns.

Parameters:

  • x (float)

  • y (float)

  • z (float)

  • strength (float)

  • radius (float)

step(n_steps=1)[source]

Advance the simulation by n_steps timesteps.

Implements the 3D wave equation with absorbing boundaries.

Parameters:

n_steps (int)

get_total_coherence()[source]

Calculate Q: spatial coherence metric (3D version).

Measures how organized/coordinated the field is across the volume.

Return type:

float

get_consciousness_metric()[source]

Calculate C_bio: consciousness observable (3D version).

C_bio = Q³ × ∫|ρ_coh|·|∂L/∂t| dV

Uses Q³ (stronger than 2D’s Q²) because 3D chaotic dynamics accumulate more activity volume. The cubic penalty ensures consciousness requires strong coherence, not just activity.

Return type:

float

get_field_energy()[source]

Get total field energy.

Return type:

float

reset()[source]

Reset simulation to initial state.

class visualizations.interactive.LoomfieldVisualizer3D(grid_size=48)[source]

Interactive 3D visualization of the Loomfield.

Provides three layers of engagement: - Layer 1 (Passive): Auto-rotating, caption-friendly - Layer 2 (Presenter): Preset paths, one-click scenarios - Layer 3 (Explorer): Full controls, metrics, debug views

visualizations.interactive.create_volumetric_figure(sim, render_mode='volume', opacity_scale=0.5)[source]

Create a plotly figure with volumetric rendering of the Loomfield.

Parameters:

  • sim (LoomfieldSimulator3D) – The 3D Loomfield simulator

  • render_mode (str) – ‘volume’ (continuous 3D volume) or ‘isosurface’ (nested shells)

  • opacity_scale (float) – Overall opacity multiplier (0.0-1.0)

The field is visualized with a gold colorscale where: - Brighter = higher field amplitude (more coherent) - Darker = lower field amplitude

visualizations.interactive.create_healthy_preset(sim)[source]

Healthy: Phase-locked sources creating coherent interference.

Central source + shell of synchronized satellites. Should produce high Q, high C_bio, calm visual appearance.

Parameters:

sim (LoomfieldSimulator3D)

visualizations.interactive.create_pathology_preset(sim)[source]

Pathology: Incoherent sources with different frequencies.

Scattered sources, no phase-locking, chaotic interference. Should produce low Q, low C_bio, noisy visual appearance.

Parameters:

sim (LoomfieldSimulator3D)

visualizations.interactive.create_healing_preset(sim)[source]

Healing: Re-coupling toward coherence.

Sources with same frequency but phase gradients, creating organized traveling waves that converge.

Parameters:

sim (LoomfieldSimulator3D)
